content:
Thunderbird inserts the two dashes as you describe them and they are part of the accepted de-facto email standards to allow automation to recognize when the signature begins. This should occur on all occasions.

I use a plain text "almost" signature in Thunderbird. It always appears never contains preformat in the body, and it always has a signature separator. What some experimentation shows is I have the use HTML box checked. Removing the check brings in the preformat.

Try it and let me know, because it really sounds like a bug to me and I can not find anything already open. But searching Bugzilla is not one of my strengths. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Generally that sounds like a connection failure. It might have nothing to do with the password really, just that is the point of failure.

Things like, your internet connection is being dropped or is very slow so things time out, the server is down, your firewall is blocking Thunderbird accessing the internet, or your antivirus has lost the plot and is preventing mail being downloaded with it's scanning are the common causes.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Ciao, alcune domande:

  1. Si tratta di un account configurato in POP3 o in IMAP?
  2. Qual è il file system sul disco in cui è configurato il profilo di Thunderbird (Qui le istruzioni per individuare il profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird
  3. Qual è la dimensione del profilo sul disco?
  4. La posta è suddivisa in cartelle e sottocartelle o esistono cartelle con molte email?
  5. È presente un software antivirus che controlli il traffico della posta elettronica?

p.s. Le risposte arrivano sul forum support.mozilla.org Via email arriva solo una notifica all'indirizzo con cui hai fatto la registrazione al forum.
creator: @next

content:
I have a gmail account that I have been using ever since Gmail was in Beta. So it has been my general daily mail account for some 20 years. It got 10 spam emails one day last week. That was the high, other days were like four, so do not assume everyone is deluged by spam. It appear to be largely a problem in a few countries with inadequate legal controls on SPAM, like the USA.

Of last weeks spam in my spam folder one was a SPAM message, the rest were SCAMS.

I make extensive use of filtering on the local folders in Thunderbird and find they are as robust as ever. That means occasionally they appear to run no filters for an hour or so, but after than they run correctly and pick up the stuff missed earlier get mail cycles.

What might be happening is you have so many filters that they are simply not getting completed in a timely manner. It could also be you have IMAP accounts and download timing issues with the message body means that they are somewhat patchy unless you set the filter to run after junk classification if your filter looks at the message body.

It can get confusing as well if the filter itself has hundreds of conditions in it, something the manual filtering of SPAM crowd tend to end up with or those with manual blocklists of sending addresses.

Finally you get access to the text that is displayed in the message contents when you read the email from a filter. So if the URL is not in the body of the email and visible as such, you will not be able to filter on it. You can not access the HTML source of the mail with a filter.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thank you for the quick response Matt!

Regarding getting "deluged", I was exaggerating somewhat. I actually get the same amount of spam that you get.

More specifically, I have to say that the spam/scam filtering actually does work sometimes, but doesn't work other times - even when I repeatedly manually run the spam filter. So what I'm getting at is that there should be some sort of filtering diagnostic, e.g., if the filtering isn't working properly, I should get a message saying so, and why it failed. I'd really like to get this problem fixed.

I can send some of these problem scam/spam emails to some support agent there and say what I am filtering on so they can verify the failure themselves. But, is there any support agent available that can look into this?

Oh, regarding that URL issue. The scammers are pretty smart, so often the only way I can definitely tell it's a scam/spam message is to mouse over the message content. While there are often lots of links there, I usually find that they ALL point to one crazy-looking URL, and I find that would be a good filtering target.

Finally, is it possible for me to write an EXE file where I can do the filtering myself? That way I can be sure the filtering is working correctly.
creator: Don-Peters

content: IMAP accounts that can not connect to the server routinely disappear folders other than inbox and a couple of basic standard folders. I would guess you are having connectivity issues, not subscription issues.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Without the message source that is nothing but a red herring. But and I think this is very important here. If you send an emails to two people by including two addresses in the To: CC: or BCC: then the same email is submitted to the mail server and the same email is delivered to both recipients. The failure of one recipient to be able to read the message probably says more about their choice of mail client than anything else.

Size being unknown can be an interesting issue, as it would indicate that the message is malformed. Do these attachments have a common source, like a security camera.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I don't know Macs, but if thunderbird is still on the old machine, try this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' in left column and click 'open profile' - Now exit Thunderbird and you should be in the File manager for mac, listing the profile. - if all you want are the message folders, but not the full profile, they will be in either the Mail folder for POP accounts or Imapmail folder for IMAP accounts. If you want the entire profile, back up one folder. the folder name would probably end in 'default' or 'default-release'

- if you want the full profile, complete with account info and other settings, copy the profile folder to the same place on the new computer, again with thunderbird not running.
creator: davidsk

content:
Try disabling your antivirus, it is quite probable it is locking Thunderbird profile files to scan while it is trying to get more mail.

This is one of the reasons we recommend creating n exception in the antivirus product to exclude the profile folder from on access scanning.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
With 30k+ messages to download, you could be reaching gmail limits depending on the message sizes:

https://support.google.com/a/answer/1071518

Most users unsubscribe All Mail since it includes mail already in other folders:

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Gmail

Run Windows in safe mode (with startup apps like AV bypassed) and see if performance improves.
creator: sfhowes

content: Thanks... I just shut off 'All mail' and will try safe mode if that doesn't work....
creator: Rickz

content:
There is a reason the default sync frequency is 30 minutes. My guess is the various attempts to sync are falling over themselves so instead of becoming more frequent, they are becoming a complete failure.

You could enable full calendar logging to get full details using the config editor Set both calendar.debug.log and calendar.debug.log.verbose to true, and reload calendar pane.
creator: MattAuSupport
